Message.Title: The Cruz Amendment
Message.Msg: MENDMENT by Americas Voice Online on 05/09/2013 at 1:42pm The following is a press statement from the Congressional Hispanic Caucus on Sen. Cruz’s amendment to prohibit immigrants from ever obtaining citizenship: Today, CHC Chairman Rubén Hinojosa (TX-15) and Members of the CHC released the following statement in response to the amendment offered by Senator Ted Cruz (R-TX) that would prohibit current and former undocumented immigrants from being eligible for United States citizenship: “As the CHC outlined in our Nine Principles of Immigration Reform, we will not support any legislation that does not provide a pathway to earned citizenship for the 11 million undocumented immigrants who are living in the shadows and exploited in the black market. Blocking 11 million undocumented immigrants from ever being able to fully contribute to our country is a huge step backward for our American values. “It is disturbing that Sen. Ted Cruz refuses to move past abstract, extremist rhetoric and see immigration reform in real life terms. The American people have consistently called on Congress to find a just, sensible solution. Sen. Cruz’s amendment however, would, in effect, institutionalize an underclass. Future generations will look back at his proposal with shame and shake their heads at how the senator dismissed some of our core American values.”

Message.Title: a Brit comments on their National Health Service
Message.Msg: found this on another board: " I was born and raised in the UK, and am forever grateful to the UK National Health Service for the care and attention I received throughout the years (and yes, if I chose private care for any reason or condition, I could pay privately and still continue to use the NHS as I saw appropriate). The one startling thing about coming to America and becoming a US citizen has been trying to get my head around the utter stupidity - real, festering stupidity - of conservatives who are terrified of Universal Health Care, while having no experience of it. Care is NOT denied under the British system (American insurance companies, however, are happy to deny care when their profit margins are threatened)... and outcomes in the UK are better than in the US. And we spend less on health care! But all that underinformed Americans know of the NHS is the preposterous propaganda produced by the insurance companies, who don't give one whit about your health, just about making money out of you in your greatest need."

Topic.Title: a Brit comments on their National Health Service

Message.Msg: I use the VA, the system President Obama lauded as the very model for socialized health care. Let's just say that if this is what socialized heathcare is all about forget it. I'm "Category 1" their highest priority of service yet I have two shattered teeth in my mouth, my first new chair in 7 years has finally been ordered and will NOW be here in around eight weeks, the PT was horrified that I didn't have a backup chair when my main chair cratered, and we'll see about fixing that AFTER the broken chair is replaced (the backup chair is a manual chair that unlike my power chair will fit in a standard auto OR be used with bus/van tiedowns). As far as general medical care I haven't had a physical in perhaps 17 years now (its supposed to be done once yearly on an inpatient basis with MS patients), the Neurologist before this one was a total idiot and required direct orders NOT to touch my files or to fool himself with any pretense he was my physician, I finally found one though some 8 months in pain later . . . Oh yeah, the very example of socialized medicine. You have NO idea how frustrated I've been with the VA at times. They have if not broken my sanity at least severely bent it on several occasions.

Topic.Title: a Brit comments on their National Health Service

Message.Msg: An added FYI, the government exempted itself from the requirements of Obamacare, so I won't be getting a voucher from the government for the equivalent health care the VA would otherwise provide, instead I will be REQUIRED to continue to go to the VA so they can "control costs". Golly, imagine that, the US government exempting itself from a law that they're going to require of private industry, heaven knows we haven't ever seen THAT before!! (the list is so long that to attempt to post it would overflow the BBS post function, I just tried. Google the list yourself if your'e that bored).

Message.Title: A Wager Lost.
Message.Msg: If you're holding off on going long until it dips under $10 again, oh well, that train has left the station at this point. Now you're hoping it'll dip back under $11, and it may . . . it's entirely possible. But if you're betting your position on it then you're making a bad bet. The only thing holding the price down right now are those shares Citadel dumped on the market waiting to escape for a fast profit, but that too will shortly pass and those with shares in their hands will become increasingly unwilling to part with them as a re-computaion of their loans given the changing circumstances might indicate a floor value for the company as a multiple of its stock price on the order of eight rather than two. The funny this is that when you're playing with this much money a SLIGHT change in the outlook on what are considered bad loans makes a HUGE difference in the bottom line when suddenly they aren't so bad after all.

Message.Title: liars still repeating the lie that Congress has Exemption from ‘Obamacare’?......
Message.Msg: Congress and an Exemption from ‘Obamacare’? Posted on May 3, 2013 Q: Is it true that there are bills in Congress that would exempt members and their staffs and families from buying into “Obamacare”? A: No. Congress members and staffers will be required to buy insurance through the exchanges on Jan. 1. .. there is no bill in Congress calling for an exemption from the health care law. In fact, members of Congress and their staffs face additional requirements that most Americans don’t have to meet. Under the health care law, their insurance coverage will have to switch from the Federal Employees Health Benefits Program, the group of private insurance plans that cover 8 million federal employees and retirees, to the exchanges created by the law. Those exchanges are meant for those who buy coverage on their own, the currently uninsured and small businesses. Members of Congress and their staffs would be the only employees of a large employer in the exchanges, which are set to begin offering insurance in January. fact check dot org

Message.Title: German Healthcare
Message.Msg: Germany’s Health Care System: It’s Not The American Way by Uwe E. Reinhardt From an American perspective, Germany’s health care system represents a nettlesome challenge. Americans now spend 14 percent of their gross domestic product (GDP) on health care, while Germany spends less than 10 percent. Yet, for all that heavier spending, the U.S. health care system has never managed to provide all Americans with secure, portable health insurance. Evidently, for many low-income Americans without health insurance, the system now rations health care by income and ability to pay. By contrast, Germans of all ages have long enjoyed fully portable health insurance that provides what is effectively first-dollar coverage for a very comprehensive package of benefits. Furthermore, unlike U.S. patients, who increasingly find their choice of doctor and hospital limited through the technique of managed competition, German patients still enjoy completely free choice of provider at the time illness strikes. In cross-national opinion surveys conducted by the Louis Harris organization in conjunction with the Harvard School of Public Health, both German patients and physicians express relatively greater satisfaction with their health care system than their American counterparts express with their system.1 The relatively low level of health spending in Germany is all the more remarkable, because Germany’s population is so much older than America’s: 15.5 percent of the German population is age sixty--five or older, compared with 12.2 percent of Americans.2 In fact, the United States will attain Germany’s current age structure only in the year 2020.

Topic.Title: a Brit comments on their National Health Service

Message.Msg: Ding Ding . . . wrong again, and shows again how little you know about the VA. Priority 1 vets are all service connected either in combat, training accidents, or in some cases getting injured off the job (you'd be surprised at some of the #$%$ military folk do for "hobbies". When you work at a job requiring jumping out of airplanes, do you HAVE to go do it on your own time as well? Anyway, there are needs based categories for VA service, but they start past Category 4 or so I think (there were 8 categories last I looked, though that sort of thing changes). Tell ya what, you live in anywhere near Dallas, I want you go to in with me someday and get yourself into the system just so you know what you're dealing with. Schedule an HIV test or something like that where they might reason you wouldn't want to go through a normal provider, or complain about an old service related injury. Just get them to check you out. I want to watch. You may die of old age before you actually have an appointment with a clinician for reasons other than filtering out the lusers trying to take a free ride on the VA with the two to four years of active duty and alittle inactive service, many sometimes thinks that means they can use the VA no matter WHAT their needs status is. This is INCORRECT except in cases of receipt at an Emergency Room by ambulance in a life threatening situation. Then all they have is the duty to stabilize you and pass you on to a country hospital, for which you should be VERY thankful.

This means some troops are kept in military hospitals until it the Army AND the VA have finished their paperwork and come to a disability determination (which is good because the way the VA does it in general lis better than the way the military services do it as few are skilled with the VA disability tables the way VA docs are). The VA has serious structural issues nationwide which need addresses, however the Dallas VA regional medical center is in a state of crises. Topic.Title: Log Cabin Girls Cried All Weekend

Message.Msg: Er, I self identify mainly libertarian and if its not made up then its something I ought to know . . . What exactly differentiates a "Log Cabin" Republican from any other sort† The problem is that it's almost impossible to use one label to describe any group of people larger than one without narrowing focusing on whatever it is that group is assembled to do. Not even all members of the NRA agree on what our approach should be, from rigorous but with wider weapon ownership categories "you've got the training you can buy the weapon" types like me to those who want to ban all non rim fire weapons assuming they have one of the "characteristics of an assault weapon". You can get into the details but there are pro lifers who think ANY interference with conception is awful and you have types like me that want to keep it legal, safe, and rare. Then again I don't agree on a great many Republican positions, particularly as stated by the ignorant on this board, but I agree with far far less Democratic positions, particularly those as affect Federal Spending on entitlement programs, and, in particular among them, consideration of a complete ban on unearned entitlements. †(e.g, libertarians are like liberals who actually BELIEVE the liberal ideal rather than using it to create a government empire of bureaucracies. That being said it puts our interests in general far to the Republican side rather than the Democratic side since a Democrat never saw anything that he didn't think could be legislated, regulated, or taxed)
